messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Actually, I m sure no one wants to see me naked, just ask my wife. And yes, we are doing a 2009 Shinsa in Sydney. We are also doing a London shinsa in November
messages.messageBody:
Actually, I'm sure no one wants to see me naked, just ask my wife.

And yes, we are doing a 2009 Shinsa in Sydney. We are also doing a London shinsa
in November this year. I don't know the site yet, but will get that information out
as soon as I have the details. The contact person, as always, is the venerable
Graham Curtis.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, As I ve explained before, while the motif is the same, the workmanship of your tsuba is not identical.  Given that it was unsigned and had no unique
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
As I've explained before, while the motif is the same, the workmanship of your tsuba is not identical. Given that it was unsigned and had no unique characteristics, there was no more justification to assign it to a "den" than to assign every dragon or shishi Goto copy to den Goto. Good workmanship and materials will get a slight point bonus even if the work is not distinctive enough to get a group attribution.

In Edo period kinko and also iron sukashi there are many very similar works with signatures from unrelated groups. Fittings makers were turning out what would sell.

And Milt has now burned up all of the time that I have to respond to the list for the immediate future, so you can all thank Milt for that.

Jim

That example is signed.........so if my example is identical to the signed
tsuba, the least they can do is give me a " den " ( of the maker's in Compton's
).
May be not in the shinsa paper, but at least mention it in the yellow point
score sheet ( if quality is not there, then how come i get above average
points ? )???

So, I repeat, NO BEER FOR YOU.
LOL


milt

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 10:57 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko



Gordon,

Do you mean Jochiku?

Murakami school did cross my mind, but for sure they're not at that level.

Jim

Hi Ron and Jim,

Having seen the menuki, I would agree to the late Edo call. Also,
dragonflies are a favorite motif of Jakushi, but these do not come up to his
level of workmanship. This makes a call really hard, as Jim says, so,
Kyo-Kinko is the attribution of last resort.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
[mailto:nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>
yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 9:58 AM
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Ron,
I didn't say it was hard to date Kyo-kinko, just impossible to assign to a
group. There aren't different attributions for the different parts of the
Edo period. The NTHK does assign a period within Edo for every fitting or
koshirae paper:

初期 Shoki (the beginning)

前期 Zenki (the first part)

中期 Chuki (the middle)

後期 Koki (late)

末期 Baki (the end)

The NBTHK does not.

I can't even guess at a group on the tombo menuki, and that is the way it is
with the Kyo-kinko attribution. I didn't see them in Tampa, but based on the
photos they look like late Edo work.

Agreed with Gordon's earlier comment that there are plenty of early solid
gold menuki, including Ko-mino and Ko-Kinko work in addition to Goto. The
recent NBTHK AB display and lecture at Tampa included several pairs of solid
gold mainline Goto menuki from the Muromachi and early Edo periods.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 7:31 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Jim -

You may have seen these in Tampa but here is a link showing the menuki that
I was asking about:
http://www.nihonto <http://www.nihonto
<http://www.nihonto.com/11.3.07.html> com/11.3.07.html> com/11.3.07.html

Papered as Kyo-kinko, maybe these fall into that area as you mentioned where
it is difficult to "date" them or to assign a maker. Can you comment on
these that I purchased? Work seems very nice to my eye and I'm certainly
happy with them.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 5:36 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama
period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto
main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the
style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally
lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem
(especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with
no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific
attribution.

BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is
attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: ROBSON Gordon
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 4:23 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Hi Ron,

My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. This would

make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are post-Ko-
Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out there. I
think the
title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something like
that. Jim
is probably better up on this stuff then I am.

On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon et al, I submitted a shakudo mumei tsuba for NTHK ( your branch ) shinsa , theme  is dragon ascending Mt. Fuji. The gold ( not paint ) dragon is scale
messages.messageBody:
Gordon et al,

I submitted a shakudo mumei tsuba for NTHK ( your branch ) shinsa , theme is
dragon ascending Mt. Fuji.
The gold ( not paint ) dragon is scale for scale ( wiskers, claws too )
identical to a signed example in Compton's Christie's catalog...........all I got
back is Kyo-Kinko ( albeit good point score ), at least you guys could have
attribute it to a school ?? !!

NO BEER FOR YOU !!!!!


Milt


In a message dated 2/27/2008 7:47:27 P.M. Central Standard Time,
robsongo@... writes:




Hi Ron and Jim,

Having seen the menuki, I would agree to the late Edo call. Also,
dragonflies are a favorite motif of Jakushi, but these do not come up to his
level of workmanship. This makes a call really hard, as Jim says, so,
Kyo-Kinko is the attribution of last resort.

Gordon

Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 9:58 AM
To: _nihontostudy@nihontostudynih_ (mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com)
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Ron,
I didn't say it was hard to date Kyo-kinko, just impossible to assign to a
group. There aren't different attributions for the different parts of the
Edo period. The NTHK does assign a period within Edo for every fitting or
koshirae paper:

初期 Shoki (the beginning)

前期 Zenki (the first part)

中期 Chuki (the middle)

後期 Koki (late)

末期 Baki (the end)

The NBTHK does not.

I can't even guess at a group on the tombo menuki, and that is the way it is
with the Kyo-kinko attribution. I didn't see them in Tampa, but based on the
photos they look like late Edo work.

Agreed with Gordon's earlier comment that there are plenty of early solid
gold menuki, including Ko-mino and Ko-Kinko work in addition to Goto. The
recent NBTHK AB display and lecture at Tampa included several pairs of solid
gold mainline Goto menuki from the Muromachi and early Edo periods.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudmailto:nihontostmai> yahoogroups.
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 7:31 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Jim -

You may have seen these in Tampa but here is a link showing the menuki that
I was asking about:
_http://www.nihonto._ (http://www.nihonto./)
<_http://www.nihonto.http://wwhttp://_ (http://www.nihonto.com/11.3.07.html) > com/11.3.07.

Papered as Kyo-kinko, maybe these fall into that area as you mentioned where
it is difficult to "date" them or to assign a maker. Can you comment on
these that I purchased? Work seems very nice to my eye and I'm certainly
happy with them.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudmailto:nihontostmai> yahoogroups.
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 5:36 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama
period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto
main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the
style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally
lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem
(especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with
no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific
attribution.

BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is
attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: ROBSON Gordon
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudmailto:nihontostmai> yahoogroups.
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 4:23 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

Hi Ron,

My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. This would

make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are post-Ko-
Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out there. I
think the
title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something like
that. Jim
is probably better up on this stuff then I am.

On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, Do you mean Jochiku? Murakami school did cross my mind, but for sure they re not at that level. Jim Hi Ron and Jim, Having seen the menuki, I would
messages.messageBody:
Gordon,

Do you mean Jochiku?

Murakami school did cross my mind, but for sure they're not at that level.

Jim





Hi Ron and Jim,

Having seen the menuki, I would agree to the late Edo call. Also,
dragonflies are a favorite motif of Jakushi, but these do not come up to his
level of workmanship. This makes a call really hard, as Jim says, so,
Kyo-Kinko is the attribution of last resort.

Gordon

messages.msgSnippet: Ron, I didn t say it was hard to date Kyo-kinko, just impossible to assign to a group.  There aren t different attributions for the different parts of the Edo
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
I didn't say it was hard to date Kyo-kinko, just impossible to assign to a group. There aren't different attributions for the different parts of the Edo period. The NTHK does assign a period within Edo for every fitting or koshirae paper:

初期 Shoki (the beginning)

前期 Zenki (the first part)

中期 Chuki (the middle)

後期 Koki (late)

末期 Baki (the end)


The NBTHK does not.

I can't even guess at a group on the tombo menuki, and that is the way it is with the Kyo-kinko attribution. I didn't see them in Tampa, but based on the photos they look like late Edo work.

Agreed with Gordon's earlier comment that there are plenty of early solid gold menuki, including Ko-mino and Ko-Kinko work in addition to Goto. The recent NBTHK AB display and lecture at Tampa included several pairs of solid gold mainline Goto menuki from the Muromachi and early Edo periods.

Jim

From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Papered as Kyo-kinko, maybe these fall into that area as you mentioned where it is difficult to "date" them or to assign a maker. Can you comment on these that I purchased? Work seems very nice to my eye and I'm certainly happy with them.

Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 5:36 PM

Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem (especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific attribution.

BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Materials do play in as well.  True black shakudo or solid gold would be unlikely to be in the hands of a poor craftsman.  Kyo-kanagushi type work is usually
messages.messageBody:
Materials do play in as well. True black shakudo or solid gold would be unlikely to be in the hands of a poor craftsman. Kyo-kanagushi type work is usually done in muddy copper alloys or occasionally gold plate. The quality of the carving is not high, either.

Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: satcho.michael_harris
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 7:20 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko


Jim,

Is it then safe to say that Kyo-kanagushi is the catch-all and we
need look to the materials and workmanship to distinguish from Kyo-
kinko...or is it solely workmanship?

Michael

satcho.com
http://www.satcho.com Specialists in books related to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.
_______________________________________________

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: That s pretty much the book to have for waki-Goto.  It s a very useful resource and pretty much a must-have for fittings researchers. Jim ... From: Gordon
messages.messageBody:
That's pretty much "the" book to have for waki-Goto. It's a very useful resource and pretty much a must-have for fittings researchers.

Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 6:23 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko


Thanks Michael, a highly cogent reply. I don't have this book, but I think I
should get it.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of satcho.michael_harris
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 7:10 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko

Right on both counts Gordon...The book is:

STUDIES IN KYO GOTO
Kasahara Koju, Akimoto Shigeo (1988)
A unique text for presenting written survey in both English and
Japanese of the waki-Goto schools, the fifteen branch families of the
mainline Goto masters. Tosogu are shown full size with enlarged,
detail photographs of inscriptions. This English translation also
extends to the captions and descriptions accompanying each plate.

Picture and complete description at http://satcho.
<http://satcho.com/Tosogu.htm> com/Tosogu.htm

Michael

satcho.com
http://www.satcho. <http://www.satcho.com> com Specialists in books related
to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.
_______________________________________________

messages.msgSnippet: Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama period.  It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto main or
messages.messageBody:
Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem (especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific attribution.

BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: ROBSON Gordon
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 4:23 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko


Hi Ron,

My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. This would
make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are post-Ko-
Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out there. I think the
title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something like that. Jim
is probably better up on this stuff then I am.

On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!

Gordon




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, but gold does not equate to late in my mind despite its popular late use. The early Goto made extensive use of gold during the mid Muromachi period - as
messages.messageBody:
Yes, but gold does not equate to late in my mind despite its popular late
use. The early Goto made extensive use of gold during the mid Muromachi
period - as one would expect for a family in charge of minting.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 6:31 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko



Thanks Gordon. I do remember this now that you mentioned it. What started
all this was my trying to "date" the gold dai-sho menuki I mentioned. When I
see "gold" I tend to think "late Edo" but that's not always true. The set I
bought from Fred, being a dai-sho and of gold still makes me think late Edo;
if a single set (not made as a dai-sho) then I probably should be thinking
"maybe earlier." Oh such fun with these toys, eh?

Ron

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Michael, a highly cogent reply. I don t have this book, but I think I should get it. Gordon ... From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Michael, a highly cogent reply. I don't have this book, but I think I
should get it.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of satcho.michael_harris
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 7:10 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Kyo-kinko



Right on both counts Gordon...The book is:

STUDIES IN KYO GOTO
Kasahara Koju, Akimoto Shigeo (1988)
A unique text for presenting written survey in both English and
Japanese of the waki-Goto schools, the fifteen branch families of the
mainline Goto masters. Tosogu are shown full size with enlarged,
detail photographs of inscriptions. This English translation also
extends to the captions and descriptions accompanying each plate.

Picture and complete description at http://satcho.
<http://satcho.com/Tosogu.htm> com/Tosogu.htm

Michael

satcho.com
http://www.satcho. <http://www.satcho.com> com Specialists in books related
to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.
_______________________________________________

Thanks Gordon. I do remember this now that you mentioned it. What started all this was my trying to "date" the gold dai-sho menuki I mentioned. When I see "gold" I tend to think "late Edo" but that's not always true. The set I bought from Fred, being a dai-sho and of gold still makes me think late Edo; if a single set (not made as a dai-sho) then I probably should be thinking "maybe earlier." Oh such fun with these toys, eh?

Ron

messages.subject: Kyo-kinko
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, all - Can somebody clarify Kyo-kinko work, if that would date the work late Edo or does it simply refer to kinko work from Kyoto? I m trying to get
messages.messageBody:
Jim, all -

Can somebody clarify "Kyo-kinko" work, if that would "date" the work late Edo or does it simply refer to "kinko work from Kyoto?"

I'm trying to get a good feeling of "age" for the dai-sho "dragonfly" menuki shown on Fred's site, Nihonto.com, which are now part of my collection. I am thinking these would be pretty "late Edo" but looking at some of the other "signed" solid gold menuki, maybe I'm a hundred years off on that opinion. Comments???

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
